docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a drumbeat of research and advertising, at least 20 million Americans at risk of heart attacks are not getting cholesterol-lowering drugs that could save their lives. The latest statistics, released today at a cardiology conference here, underline one of heart experts' biggest frustrations: Even though the benefits of these medicines are now beyond dispute, they are prescribed to perhaps only one in five of those who could benefit.
docs.abstract: Latest statistics suggest that at least 20 million Americans at risk of heart attacks are not getting cholesterol-lowering drugs, called statins, that could save their lives; experts blame doctors, who are better paid for treating diseases than for preventing them, and patients, who are often reluctant to take drugs when they have no outward symptoms of heart trouble; high cost of drugs also cited (M)
docs.snippet: Despite a drumbeat of research and advertising, at least 20 million Americans at risk of heart attacks are not getting cholesterol-lowering drugs that could save their lives.    The latest statistics, released today at a cardiology conference here,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Treating back pain by shooting painless electrical impulses into muscles through fine needles brought patients modest relief and improved movement, researchers found in a study released last week. But experts not involved in the work cautioned that the patients were an unusual group and results might not be applicable to most people with back problems. Even among the 60 subjects, improvements were modest, the outside experts said. In the study, a therapy called PENS, for percutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, helped patients with chronic low-back pain feel better, move better and use less pain-relieving medicine within three weeks, the researchers reported.

headline.main: Jolts of Electricity for Aching Backs

docs.abstract: Researchers find treating back pain by shooting painless electrical impulses into muscles through fine needles brings patients modest relief and improves movement; experts caution that treatment might not be applicable to most people with back problems (S)
docs.snippet: Treating back pain by shooting painless electrical impulses into muscles through fine needles brought patients modest relief and improved movement, researchers found in a study released last week. But experts not involved in the work cautioned that...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''You know what I do when I'm angry? I hit a pillow. Try that,'' suggests the psychiatrist, played by Billy Crystal, to his New York gangster client (Robert De Niro) in the Warner Brothers movie ''Analyze This.'' But it is bad advice, according to new research by social psychologists. Though pop psychology books and articles perpetuate the notion that ''getting your anger out'' is cathartic and can help dissipate hostility, the researchers have found just the opposite: Venting anger on inanimate objects -- punching a pillow or hitting a punching bag, for example -- increases rather than decreases aggressive behavior.

headline.main: Letting Out Aggression Is Called Bad Advice

docs.abstract: Researchers find that venting anger on inanimate objects--punching pillow or hitting punching bag--increases rather than decreases aggressive behavior; find books and articles that recommend 'catharsis' as good method of dealing with anger actually may foster aggression by giving people permission to relax their self-control; studies appear in The Journal of Personality and Social Psychology; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women trying to become pregnant are careful to avoid ingesting any substance that might impair their fertility or damage a developing embryo. According to a new study, several popular herbal remedies should be added to the list of substances that could have detrimental effects on men as well as women and could interfere with conception or a healthy pregnancy. Despite the widespread belief, often fostered by advertising copy, that herbal preparations are ''natural'' and ''drug-free,'' those that have druglike effects in the body do in fact contain potent chemicals that act like drugs.

headline.main: Herbal Remedies Tied to Pregnancy Risks

docs.abstract: New study finds several popular herbal remedies might intefere with conception or healthy pregnancy; researchers found St John's wort, Echinacea purpura and Ginkgo biloba had ill effects on either eggs or sperm or both; findings published in current issue of Fertility and Sterility, journal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago I wrote a column that might have been called ''the myth of the negative mammogram.'' In it I discussed the fact that 10 percent to 15 percent of breast cancers do not show up on a mammogram and cautioned women that any suspicious area in the breast should be biopsied even when the mammogram is negative. Last month, I became living proof of the value of that advice. I'd been having annual mammograms for about 13 years with no evidence of anything wrong. Likewise at my exam this year, my radiologist for the last eight years, Dr. Doreen Liebeskind, delivered the news that my X-rays looked fine. However, this time I feared something was the matter.

headline.main: Living Proof: Mammograms Are Not Always Enough

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column repeats advice she offered in column 10 years ago that any suspicious area in breast should be biopsied even when mammogram is negative; says early discovery of cancer cells in her breast is living proof of value of that advice (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It had been over two years since my last visit to the gym, and it was beginning to show. While on a business trip last December, I was dismayed when I stepped out of the shower into a bathroom that could have doubled as a shrine to Narcissus. I noticed that the abdominal six-pack I once maintained almost effortlessly was threatening to become a keg. The shoulders that had given my body a horizon line, sagged so that they were hard to differentiate from my lower trunk. And the arms, while never pythons, were once sinewy cobras that could have belonged to a dancer. Now they were garden snakes. I resolved to do something about my physical deterioration. But one reason I quit running, rowing, walking and lifting free weights was because of the mind-numbing repetition. And I lacked the time. What I needed was one exercise that would address cardiovascular fitness, grace, balance, flexibility, muscular strength and that was also, well, kind of fun.

headline.main: Brazilian Martial Art for Mind and Body

docs.abstract: Eric V Copage article on capoeira, which combines dance, martial art, music and philosophy; it was developed four centuries ago by African slaves in Brazil; drawings of basic movements (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Should patients be able to sue their health maintenance organizations? ALISHA BERGER If somebody is hurt as a result of the improper decisions of an H.M.O., he should be able to sue that H.M.O. and be compensated for the damage. The purpose of the right to sue is to serve as a deterrent against conduct by an H.M.O. that is in reckless disregard of a patient's needs. The Erisa (Employee Retirement Income Security Act) statute, enacted in the 1970's, keeps states from establishing causes of action and keeps patients from suing in state courts. But the statute also says a person can sue in Federal court. If the patient prevails, though, he can get only the service that was originally denied or its dollar value.

headline.main: In Search of Fairness in Patient Care

docs.abstract: Pro & Con: question of whether patients should be able to sue their health maintenance organizations is answered in affirmative by Ron Pollack of Families USA Foundation, and in negative by Richard I Smith of American Assn of Health Plans (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many children as young as 10 years old want to know more about sex than just where babies come from, but parents often shy away from discussing sexuality, according to a national survey conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now, a children's advocacy group. Topics that may have parents blushing even in discussions with teen-agers have filtered down to children ages 10 to 12. In a random-sample telephone survey of 161 children in that age group and 447 parents, more than 40 percent of the children said they wanted to know how to handle peer pressure, how to know when they were ready for sexual activity and how alcohol and drugs might affect their decisions.

headline.main: Getting Beyond the Birds and the Bees

docs.abstract: National survey conducted by Kaiser Family Foundation and Children Now finds parents often shy away from discussing sexuality with their children, other than having simple 'birds and bees' talk; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a common, yet horrifying image. A traffic accident, a shooting, a fall or a stabbing. And the victim lies dead in a pool of blood, life drained away by severe hemorrhaging that could not be stopped in time. As blood is the fluid of life, the loss of it can be the harbinger of death. Blood loss through wounds claims tens of thousands of lives each year, but researchers are working to change that by developing a type of bandage that clots blood instantly.

headline.main: New Bandage Could Avert Thousands of Deaths

docs.abstract: Researchers are working to develop type of bandage that clots blood instantly, to prevent some of tens of thousands of deaths caused each year by blood loss through wounds; scientists with American Red Cross and researchers with United States Army have produced bandages and other dressings they say can seal severe, bleeding wound in seconds with tough, artificial scab; if dressings prove effective and safe in human trials, they could radically change emergency treatment for civilians and soldiers; drawings; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Linda Cherny played a mean game of volleyball at the Empire State Games in Syracuse a few weeks back. A 36-year-old day care provider from Kingston, N.Y., she spiked hard and jumped high. And, she says, she owes it all to her shorts. Some scientists believe her. In a five-year study, Dr. William Kraemer, the director of research and a professor of applied physiology at Pennsylvania State University, tested hundreds of male and female athletes of all ages, abilities and fitness levels and found that wearing form-fitting shorts, also known as compression garments, increases an athlete's power output and endurance, two important measures of athletic performance, by an average of 12 percent and by as much as 30 percent. The study, which tested athletes after they jumped and ran, was sponsored by DuPont, the maker of Lycra Power garments.

headline.main: Power Dressing on the Playing Field

docs.abstract: Five-year study that tested hundreds of male and female athletes of all ages, abilities and fitness levels finds that wearing form-fitting shorts, known as compression garments, increases athlete's power output and endurance by exerting pressure on muscles; photo (S)
